content.text: Determine the SI base units of stress
Show your working
base units .........
Determine \(E\) in GPa
The quantities used to determine \(E\) should be measured with accuracy and with precision
1. Explain the difference between accuracy and precision
accuracy:
precision:

In a particular experiment, the quantities \(l\) and \(T\) are measured with the same percentage uncertainty. State and explain which of these two quantities contributes more to the uncertainty in the value of \(E\)
[Total: 8]
A beam PQ is clamped so that the beam is horizontal. A mass \(M\) of \(500 \text{g}\) is hung from end Q and the beam bends slightly, as illustrated in Fig. 1.1

The length \(l\) of the beam from the edge of the clamp R to end Q is \(60.0 \text{cm}\). The width \(b\) of the beam is \(30.0 \text{mm}\) and the thickness \(d\) of the beam is \(5.00 \text{mm}\). The material of the beam has Young modulus \(E\)
The mass \(M\) is made to oscillate vertically. The time period \(T\) of the oscillations is \(0.58 \text{s}\)
The period \(T\) is given by the expression
State the two conditions for a system to be in equilibrium
Show that the acceleration of P is \(1.4 \text{m s}^{-2}\) at time \(t = 5.0 \text{s}\)
Calculate the total distance moved by P from time \(t = 0\) to \(t = 7.0 \text{s}\)
distance = .........m
Calculate the change in kinetic energy of P from time \(t = 0\) to \(t = 7.0 \text{s}\)
change in kinetic energy = .........J
The tension in the wire at time \(t = 5.0 \text{s}\) is 280 N
Calculate, for the horizontal motion,
the vertical lift force \(F\) supporting P,
2. the force \(R\) due to air resistance acting on P in the horizontal direction
A paraglider P of mass \(95\mathrm{kg}\) is pulled by a wire attached to a boat, as shown in Fig. 2.1
The wire makes an angle of \(25^{\circ}\) with the horizontal water surface. P moves in a straight line parallel to the surface of the water
The variation with time \(t\) of the velocity \(v\) of P is shown in Fig. 2.2
A cylinder is made from a material of density \(2.7 \text{g} \text{cm}^{- 3}\). The cylinder has diameter \(2.4 \text{cm}\) and length \(5.0 \text{cm}\)
Show that the cylinder has weight \(0.60 \text{N}\)
Explain what is meant by centre of gravity
Calculate the weight of X
weight of X = .........N
The cylinder in **(a)** is hung from the end A of a non-uniform bar AB, as shown in Fig. 3.1
The bar has length \(50\mathrm{cm}\) and has weight \(0.25\mathrm{N}\). The centre of gravity of the bar is \(20\mathrm{cm}\) from B. The bar is pivoted at P. The pivot is \(12\mathrm{cm}\) from B
An object X is hung from end B. The weight of X is adjusted until the bar is horizontal and in equilibrium
Explain the origin of the upthrust
Explain why the weight of X must be reduced in order to obtain equilibrium for AB
[Total: 10]
The cylinder is now immersed in water, as illustrated in Fig. 3.2
An upthrust acts on the cylinder and the bar is not in equilibrium
State the conditions required for the formation of stationary waves
Calculate the distance AB
distance = .........m
On Fig. 4.2, sketch the position of the string between A and B at times
\(t = t_1 + 2.0 \text{ms}\) (label this line P),
\(t = t_1 + 5.0 \text{ms}\) (label this line Q)
[Total: 7]
One end of a string is attached to a vibrator. The string is stretched by passing the other end over a pulley and attaching a load, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1

The frequency of vibration of the vibrator is adjusted to \(250\mathrm{Hz}\) and a transverse wave travels along the string with a speed of \(12\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). The wave is reflected at the pulley and a stationary wave forms on the string
Fig. 4.2 shows the string between points A and B at time \(t = t_1\)
At time \(t = t_1\) the string has maximum displacement
Describe the Doppler effect

A car travels with a constant velocity along a straight road. The car horn with a frequency of \(400\mathrm{Hz}\) is sounded continuously. A stationary observer on the roadside hears the sound from the horn at a frequency of \(360\mathrm{Hz}\)
The speed of sound is \(340\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\)
Determine the magnitude \(v\), and the direction, of the velocity of the car relative to the observer
direction

A cell X of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 1.5 V and negligible internal resistance is connected in series to three resistors A, B and C, as shown in Fig. 6.1

Resistors A and B have resistances \(6.0 \Omega\) and \(3.0 \Omega\) respectively and are connected in parallel. Resistor C has resistance \(4.0 \Omega\) and is connected in series with the parallel combination
Calculate
Explain how the resistors may be made with different resistance values
Calculate the ratio
average drift speed of the charge carriers in resistor B
average drift speed of the charge carriers in resistor C

cell X,
resistor C

the charge on a proton is \(+e\),
